Award.AbstractNarration: The Appalachian Set Theory (AST) workshop series was created by the PI and co-PI under NSF Award 0631446. We propose to continue this innovative workshop series as it was originally conceived. We hold three workshops per year, each devoted to a single topic such as a broadly applicable method, a complex seminal paper or a significant unpublished theorem. Faculty and students who are not experts are immersed in the subject for one or two intensive days and get the tools they need to continue on their own. The location and topic is announced several months in advance. Each workshop is led by one or two experts in the topic. This could mean doing all the lecturing themselves, or delegating parts to others. Typically, there are three hours of lectures in the morning (with short breaks), two hours for lunch, and three hours of lectures in the afternoon (with short breaks). Those wishing to attend a workshop may apply to have some of their travel expenses reimbursed. We hire one or two student participants to prepare typed notes based on the lectures with help from the workshop leader or leaders. These lecture notes are disseminated online. At least one publisher has expressed interest in publishing a collection of these lecture notes as part of a mathematics book series. In planning these workshops, special emphasis is given to encouraging participation by young mathematicians and mathematicians from underrepresented groups, efforts that have been reasonably successful.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Appalachian Set Theory is a series of mathematics workshops on set theory,
which has been supported by National Science Foundation conference grants
DMS 0631446 and DMS 0903845, and by various host universities and
institutes.  The workshops have taken place in the Appalachian region and
neighboring regions such as the Midwest and Canada.  There have been
approximately three workshops per year, each devoted to a single topic such
as a broadly applicable method, a complex seminal paper or a significant
unpublished theorem. The location, leader and topic of each workshop is
announced several months in advance together with suggested background
reading. The immediate goal is for faculty and students who are not experts
in the particular workshop topic to get to the point where they can start to
use its techniques in one or two intensive days. Each workshop day consists
of about six hours of lectures by a workshop leader; such long lectures are
required to reach a useful level of depth.  NSF and other funds were used to
reimburse some of the travel expenses of some of the participants with
preference going to 1) students, 2) postdoctoral faculty and 3) other
faculty who do not have their own grants.  Special emphasis was given to
encouraging the participation of mathematicians from underrepresented
groups.  For each workshop, one or two students were hired to generate notes
that were disseminated on the Appalachian Set Theory webpage,
http://www.math.cmu.edu/~eschimme/Appalachian/Index.html.
Later, some of these teams of workshop leaders and student note-takers
collaborated to write chapters for a book edited by the PI and co-PI and
published at the end of 2012 by Cambridge University Press in the Lecture
Notes in Mathematics series. (Each chapter was anonymously refereed by one
or two readers; in each case, the students were the second authors.)
Appalachian Set Theory has made important contributions in support of
mathematics research, mathematical collaboration, and the formation and
careers of young mathematicians.
